p: S. officinalis grows in the form of an outcrossing, perennial subshrub up to 60 cm high. The leaves are opposite and simple with white hairs on the lower leaf surface and greenish or greenish-grey on the upper surface. Stems are erect or procumbent with abundant hairy dark green branches. Leaves are elongated and petiolate with a serrate margin, rugose surface, and sometimes with basal lobes. The flowers are 2–4 mm long from the pedicel, and they are in pseudoverticillasters with 5–10 violet-blue color flowers that form spurious, composed spikes. They bloom from March to July depending on habitat and climatic conditions [ 4, 5].
